title: Pre-Hackathon Reading Material
text:
To ensure all participants are equipped to make the most of the hackathon, we’ve compiled a list of pre-read materials and resources. These resources cover essential skills for collaborative coding, R programming, and Git/GitHub workflows.



Git and GitHub: Collaborative coding will be a core component of the hackathon. Please review the following materials to ensure you’re familiar with these tools:

Introduction to GitHub
GitHub for Beginners
More GitHub Tips

R Programming: Many of the hackathon activities will involve R. The following resources will help you get up to speed:

Introduction to R
R for Data Science

R Package Development: For those interested in contributing to package development or using custom R packages:

R Packages Book





Before the event, ensure the following are installed and set up on your laptop:

R
RStudio
Git

If you need assistance with installation, refer to the guides linked above, or feel free to reach out to us prior to the hackathon.



For any queries about the resources or preparation, contact:

Waithera Mwangi: waithera.mwangi@cema.africa
Noel Likalamu: noel.likalamu@cema.africa

For any queries about setting your software up, contact:

OJ Watson: o.watson15@imperial.ac.uk

By familiarising yourself with these resources, you’ll be ready to contribute effectively and make the most of your hackathon experience.
We look forward to seeing you all in Nairobi soon!

text:

title: Kemunto Ogutu
text:
Kemunto is a communications professional working for the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA) in the Health Communications department.

title: Paul Lietar
text:
Paul Liétar is a senior research software engineer at Imperial College London, working on building software tools to assist scientists in their research.

title: George Kamundia Mbugua
text:
George Kamundia is a data science intern at the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA), applying data analytics to inform public health decision-making. He focuses on developing predictive models and tools that bridge the gap between data science and health policy, contributing to more effective disease control and prevention strategies.

title: Martin M Thendu.qmd
text: Back to top

title: Kariithi Anne Wanjiku
text:
Anne is a computer at the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis, developing data algorithms, pipelines, and database management systems to support public health policymaking. She hopes to advance her studies in biomedical engineering to improve patient outcomes through innovative applications in computational bioengineering. By integrating her engineering expertise with her passion for healthcare accessibility, she aims to advance healthcare technology, especially in underserved communities.

title: John Ojal
text:
John Ojal is a post-doctoral researcher at the Kenya Medical Research Institute - Wellcome Trust, focusing on epidemiological modeling and health economics, with contributions to studies on pneumococcal vaccination and COVID-19 in Kenya


 Back to top

title: John Nalwa
text:
John Wakhungu is a software developer at InnoSoft Technologies, specializing in custom software development, data analysis, and web applications. He is passionate about leveraging technology to solve real-world challenges, including public health innovation and data-driven solutions.

title: Fred Nyamitago Monari
text:
Fred Nyamitago Monari is a statistician and lecturer at Kisii University with extensive expertise in applied statistics, epidemiological modeling, and public health data analysis. His work focuses on leveraging advanced statistical methods and interdisciplinary collaboration to address pressing challenges in health, climate, and environmental research.


 Back to top

title: Sabine Van Elsland
text:
Sabine van Elsland is the external relationships and communications manager at the MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis at Imperial College London. Sabine is a trained infectious disease epidemiologist with a background in public health and health systems research. She has a passion for sustainable knowledge translation (evidence to policy decision making) and transparent, accessible science communication.


 Back to top

title: Waithera Mwangi
text:
Waithera is an Administration Officer at CEMA, dedicated to ensuring smooth operations and effective coordination for trainings that take place at the organisation.


 Back to top

title: Geoffrey Githinji
text:
Geoffrey is a research fellow at CEMA working of models of malaria interventions. In this role, he is supporting national malaria control programs by leveraging disease modelling and data analytics to inform strategic decisions and operational plans.


 Back to top

title: Augustine Masinde
text: Back to top

title: Triza Shigoli
text:
Triza Shigoli is a Project Management and Organizational Development professional, and the Administrative Manager at the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA), with experience in supporting the delivery of health research projects in collaboration with a multidisciplinary team of scientists and technical experts.


 Back to top

title: Muchiri Antony Mutwiri
text:
Muchiri Antony M is a software engineer intern at CEMA, where he works on optimizing various aspects of the CEMA Analytics Hub. With a strong foundation in technology and problem-solving, he is dedicated to developing impactful solutions that address real-world challenges.


 Back to top

title: Daniel Biftu Bekalo
text:
I am a PhD student in Statistics at the Pan African University Institute for Basic Sciences, Technology, and Innovation, which is hosted by Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology in Kenya. My PhD research focuses on Bayesian estimate of a latent traits model defined by a rank-based likelihood, which is in line with the hackathon’s objective of creating data-driven tools for evidence-based public health decision-making in Kenya and other resource-constrained situations.


 Back to top

title: Giovanni Charles
text:
Giovanni Charles is a software/ML engineer working on surrogates for infectious disease transmission models for inference and optimisation. He is interested in normalising flows, LLM interfaces for ID models, surrogate modelling, Bayesian inference, time-series prediction, differentiable agent based modelling and JAX.

title: Mutono Nyamai
text:
Mutono is a data scientist currently using applied epidemiological modelling techniques to provide evidence for control and elimination of Neglected Tropical Diseases.


 Back to top

title: Katy Gaythorpe
text:
Dr Katy Gaythorpe is the research lead of the Vaccine Impact Modelling Consortium (VIMC, https://www.vaccineimpact.org/) and a lecturer in the epidemiology of vaccine-preventable diseases (VPDs) at Imperial College London. Her research focuses on developing mathematical models of infectious diseases such as yellow fever and others to assess the health impacts of vaccination. Dr Gaythorpe is particularly interested in the implications of climate change for climate-sensitive VPD control.


 Back to top

title: Pius Kariuki
text:
Pius Kariuki is a digital health engineer at IntelliSOFT consulting, working with cross sectional data with tools like DHIS2. I am also an interoperability and integrations expert working with standards like FHIR and FHIR-data-pipes to report patient data.


 Back to top

title: Pete Winskill
text:
Pete Winskill is a Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation-funded research fellow at the MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis, Imperial College London and the Director of the Translational Modelling Hub. He leads the development of a global malaria modelling framework, linking the Imperial malariasimulation model to primary data to support global, national, and sub-national malaria modelling requests.


 Back to top

title: Dominic Makana Ocharo
text:
Dominic Makana Ocharo is a telecommunications engineer and data scientist based in Kenya, specializing in developing AI-driven solutions and data analytics tools to address public health challenges and optimize decision-making in resource-constrained settings.

title: Bonventure Ameyo
text:
Dr. Ameyo has gathered experience both in the practice and delivery of healthcare, its programming and management in the public sector in Kenya, currently working as the deputy director medical services in Turkana County, Kenya.


 Back to top

title: Lilith Whittles
text:
Lilith Whittles is a researcher at Imperial College London, studying the transmission of infectious diseases through human populations. Her work spans a broad spectrum: from epidemic response to mpox, COVID-19 and group A streptococcus in the UK and Europe, to reducing the impact of globally endemic sexually transmitted infections such as gonorrhoea, HIV and HSV-2.

title: Moses Muriithi
text:
Moses Muriithi is an health economist and an associate professor at the university of Nairobi department of economics and development studies cost effectiveness of various diseases interventions in the era of digital technology.

title: Cosmas Biwott
text:
Bruno Adul is yet to graduate from Delhi Technological University with a Bachelor of Technology degree in Information Technology. During his academic journey, he actively participated in various projects, including developing a school management system, a machine learning algorithm for predicting student grades, and a deep learning model to identify two-wheeler traffic violators. Currently, Bruno is applying his expertise as a Computer Science intern at CEMA, where he focuses on Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning. He aims to deepen his experience in these technologies and contribute to the fight against tropical diseases.


 Back to top

title: Stanley Sayianka
text:
Stanley Sayianka is a Data Science Research Assistant at the Centre for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA). His work focuses on the statistical modeling of mortality indicators.


 Back to top

title: Omar Ahmed
text:
My name is Omar Ahmed, and I am currently pursuing my Master’s in Public Health. I work in public health in Mombasa County, where I focus on designing and implementing health programs to improve community well-being. My thesis research explores the association between malaria prevalence in children under five and demographic, socio-economic, and environmental factors in Mogadishu. I am passionate about using evidence-based approaches to tackle public health challenges, especially in vulnerable populations. I’m excited to be here and look forward to learning and collaborating with all of you.”


 Back to top

title: Yusuf Ajack.qmd
text:
Yusuf Ajack is a distinguished researcher with a focus on public health and immunization strategies in Kenya. His work has significantly contributed to understanding the dynamics of vaccination coverage and the impact of socio-political factors on public health initiatives.
Ajack’s affiliation with the Ministry of Health in Nairobi from 2015 to 2016 provided him with valuable insights into the challenges and opportunities within the Kenyan healthcare system. His research has addressed critical issues such as the effects of religious and community influences on vaccination uptake, as evidenced by his study on the boycott called by Catholic bishops in 2015, which examined its impact on polio vaccination coverage in Kenya.
In addition to his work on polio, Ajack has also investigated the implications of infectious disease outbreaks, notably documenting the rubella outbreak in a rural Kenyan district in 2014. His findings underscored the urgent need for routine rubella immunization, highlighting the importance of proactive health measures in preventing disease spread.
Through his publications in reputable journals such as the Pan African Medical Journal and BMC Infectious Diseases, Ajack continues to advocate for improved public health policies and practices, aiming to enhance vaccination coverage and overall health outcomes in Kenya.


 Back to top

title: Ivy Kombe
text:
Ivy Kombe is a computational epidemiologist at the Kenya Medical Research Institute - Wellcome Trust, specializing in mathematical models of infectious disease dynamics, with experience in modeling HIV, COVID-19, and respiratory syncytial virus.

veronica chege is a software engineer focused on identifying and addressing gaps in the healthcare system. With a strong problem-solving mindset, she collaborates with subject-matter experts to apply engineering solutions to improve healthcare outcomes.

Paula Christen is social scientist and infectious disease epidemiologist specialized in researching, identifying and developing interventions enabling knowledge translation from infectious disease models to public health policy and programs.

title: Tabitha Okech
text:
Tabitha Okech is a dedicated Public Health Practitioner and Pharmacist based in Nairobi, Kenya, with over a decade of experience in managing preventive and promotive public health programs.

title: Thumbi Mwangi
text:
Thumbi Mwangi Co-Director & Group Lead (Applied Epidemiology) at CEMA, leading efforts in epidemiological modelling and public health policy in Africa. He is an infectious disease epidemiologist combining classical epidemiology, applied epidemiological modelling and data science to improve the speed and quality of policy decision making in human and animal health


 Back to top

title: Amika Patel
text:
I am Amika Patel, a data analyst at the Nairobi West Hospital. With experience in healthcare operations and a passion for using data to drive evidence-based policies, I am keen to bridge the gap between analytics and real-world decision-making.


 Back to top

title: Joy Kalekye Nthiwa
text:
Joy Nthiwa is a PhD scholar in the Department of Medical Microbiology and Immunology. She is also a fellow of the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA) under the African Modeling and Analytics Academy for Women (AMAX) project. With a background in Statistics and Actuarial Science, her research interests focus on schistosomiasis, specifically on the use of mathematical models to optimize the delivery of intervention strategies for the elimination of schistosomiasis in Kenya.


 Back to top

title: Arani Bonsoul
text:
I am Bonsoul Arani Bosire, a data scientist and analyst with over three years of experience in the data industry. I specialize in leveraging machine learning, statistical analysis, and scalable Python solutions to drive business growth and deliver actionable insights. My expertise spans data visualization, competitive analysis, and sales forecasting, enabling me to improve processes, optimize resources, and enhance decision-making.


 Back to top

title: Jackline Mosinya Nyaberi
text:
Nyaberi is a public health and health systems expert researcher at the School of Public Health, Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology. She is an accomplished Global Health leader and advisor. She is an inaugural Fellow of the Kofi Annan (She is a such a resource for the continent and beyond). She is a 24/7 mentor to aspiring leaders in professional and Personal Development. She is a holistic trainer, mentor and coach at Authentic Leadership for Development (ALD) for Corporate Solutions. She is an author of “101 Authentic Leadership Lessons: Impacting African Leaders. Jackline’s career has focused on strengthening ethics, leadership and governance, health systems, and public health leadership to improve infectious disease preparedness and to reduce mortality, morbidity, and disability in vulnerable communities. Her career accomplishments include formulating new health programs, policies, and strategies in 55 Africa Union Member states to support pandemic preparedness plans, health workforce planning, leadership and governance, and strengthening health systems. Jackline is inspired to mentor adolescents, women, and girls, provides basic school items for low-income children in rural settings, and founded Ayanna Health Foundation, a non-profit which provides mentorship, empowerment and health services to vulnerable populations and mentorship. Jackline holds a Master of Public Health from Maseno University in Kenya, a Master of Global Bioethics from Anahuac University in Mexico, and a Ph.D. in Public Health from Kenyatta University in Kenya. Jackline was named a 2021 Inaugural Kofi Annan Global Health Leadership Fellow by the Kofi Annan Foundation, Africa CDC and African Union. Long term, Jackline hopes to continue her work in strengthening public health systems in Africa and beyond and to activate the next generation to become transformational leaders. She dreams to support not only health systems in Africa to experience a paradigm shift in governance and leadership, but also to support all interconnected ecosystems of all stakeholders to foster health and wellbeing for all generations. jnyaberij@gmail.com https://www.linkedin.com/in/mosinyanyaberi/


 Back to top

title: Oliver (OJ) Watson
text:
OJ Watson is a lecturer and Schmidt AI in science fellow at Imperial College London, with a background in infectious disease modelling in malaria, and interest in pandemic preparedness.


 Back to top

title: Cosmas Biwott
text:
Cosmas Biwott is a statistician at the University of Nairobi’s Centre for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (UoN-CEMA). Specializing in applying advanced statistical methods to health data, driving evidence-based decision-making to improve public health outcomes.


 Back to top

title: Ruth Mc Cabe
text:
Ruth McCabe is a statistician and mathematical modeller at Imperial College London specialising in outbreak response at the science-policy interface.


 Back to top

title: Salmon Gowa
text:
Salmon Gowa is a software developer with a passion for using technology to address public health challenges. Proficient in software development and data analysis, he’s eager to create impactful, open-source tools to support evidence-based policymaking in Kenya.


 Back to top

title: Evans Omondi
text:
Evans Omondi is a mathematician and Post-Doctoral Research Scientist (Mathematical modeler) at the African Population and Health Research Center (APHRC) in Kenya. I have a broad background in the application of mathematical modeling applied to biology, with particular expertise in dynamical systems and stochastic processes for modeling infectious diseases.

title: Kibet Immanuel Ngeno

I am kibet Immanuel, a full-stack software engineer with a passion for developing innovative solutions that bridge technology and real-world needs. My expertise lies in creating scalable and impactful software especially in collaborative environments.

title: Jeanette Dawa
text:
Jeanette Dawa (MBChB, MSc, PhD) is a public health specialist/epidemiologist with a background in medicine, public health and infectious disease modelling.

title: Registration
text:
• We want to: Create free, open-source resources to support and facilitate evidence-informed decision making and address health policy needs in Kenya.
• We are looking for:

Public Health Decision-Makers: Ministry of Health officials and public health specialists who provide insights based on real-world public health needs and ensure developed tools address practical challenges.
Developers and Technical Experts: Individuals proficient in R programming, version control using Git and GitHub, epidemiological modelling, and software development.
Academics and Researchers: Participants from various Kenyan institutions, not limited to CEMA, who are involved in infectious disease modelling and public health data analysis.

• We aim to: maximize diversity in skills, experiences, and people.
• Applications close on the 3rd December 2024.

Developers and Technical Experts: Individuals proficient in R programming, version control using Git and GitHub, epidemiological modelling, and software development.

• Applications close on the 3rd December 2024.

title: Registration
text:
Registration
Please register your interest using this Google Form

title: Bridging the Gap Hackathon
text:
The “Bridging the Gap Hackathon” is a 5-day event to bring together public health decision-makers, developers, technical experts, and academics and researchers to create free, open-source resources to support and facilitate evidence-informed decision making and address health policy needs in Kenya.

Background
Experiences during the COVID-19 pandemic highlighted the challenges decision makers face in interpreting and using analytics for public health policy. To respond to these challenges, researchers at the MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis (MRC-GIDA) at Imperial College London and the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA) at the University of Nairobi are currently conducting a research study to explore how the gap between quantitative scientists and policymakers, especially in resource-constrained settings can be bridged.


Who Should Attend
The hackathon aims to include a diverse audience, who will either contribute to idea generation or developing the identified software tools. The latter activity will include core training on collaborative coding best practices, which will be strengthened by the delivery of pre-hackathon virtual training courses and teaching material for enrolled participants.

Health Decision-Makers & Providers: Ministry of Health officials, health organizations and public health specialists who provide insights based on real-world public health needs and/or ensure developed tools address practical challenges.
Developers and Technical Experts: Individuals proficient in R programming, version control using Git and GitHub, epidemiological modelling, and software development.
Academics and Researchers: Participants from various Kenyan institutions, not limited to CEMA, who are involved in infectious disease modelling and public health data analysis.

This activity is restricted to up to 30 applicants residing in Kenya.


Cost
There is no cost to attend the hackathon, however, there are a limited number of places available for the hackathon. While we do have some funds to support travel and attendance for participants from outside Nairobi and from MRC-GIDA at Imperial College London, these funds are limited. If you require financial support to attend, please indicate this in the registration form.


Registration
Registration Is Now Closed!
Please register your interest for the hackathon using the link above by 3 December 24. We will then be in touch to confirm participant funding and attendance, which will be allocated to ensure a diverse range of participants and backgrounds.


Hackathon Schedule

Day 1: Foundations and Group Formation

Introductions, icebreaker activities, and team building exercises.
Sharing of real-world challenges presented by Ministry of Health, health organizations and/or public health specialists.
Formation of interdisciplinary teams focused on specific public health challenges.
Overview of Git, Github and collaborative coding practices (GitHub training should have been completed before attending the course).

Days 2-3: Coding and Collaboration

Dedicated project work time with guidance from experienced facilitators.
Continuous interaction and feedback sessions to refine ideas and approaches.

Day 4: Presentation and Feedback

Teams present their minimum viable products to Ministry of Health representatives and other stakeholders.
Constructive feedback and discussions on the relevance and potential impact of the tools developed.

Day 5: Refinement and Next Steps

Project refinement based on the feedback received.
Planning for further development, implementation, and potential scaling of the tools.
Closing remarks and celebration of achievements.




Venue
The hackathon will be hosted by the Center for Epidemiological Modelling and Analysis (CEMA). The training will take place at the Smart Classroom, 11th Floor, University of Nairobi, University of Nairobi Towers at Main Campus/Nairobi CBD.


Sponsors
We are extremely grateful to our sponsors for the hackathon:

MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis at Imperial College London (MR/X020258/1) for their support of the hackathon, including supporting researchers from Kenya and the United Kingdom to attend and providing resources for the hackathon.
Wellcome for funding the study inspiring the hackathon (“Leveraging forecasts to optimise decision making” - 228271/Z/23/Z), which supported the original Ideathon team to travel for the hackathon.
The Gates Foundation (INV-044079) for supporting involvement of CEMA staff in the hackathon.
